title: A Secret in the Attic
description: A playful mystery where friends find a dusty trunk and piece together a family story using clues and imagination.

pages.text: It all began on a rainy afternoon when Emma and Oliver decided to explore the old attic.
pages.illustration: Emma and Oliver climbing a wooden ladder into a dim attic filled with boxes, beams, and soft sunlight filtering through a window.

pages.text: The air smelled like old paper and pine dust. A single beam of light landed on a trunk tucked beneath a blanket.
pages.illustration: A dusty attic corner with cobwebs, sunbeam highlighting an old trunk half-covered by a faded quilt.

pages.text: “Look!” said Emma. “It’s locked!” But Oliver noticed a golden key glinting beside a stack of letters.
pages.illustration: Close-up of Oliver reaching toward a small golden key near yellowed envelopes and books.

pages.text: With a soft click, the trunk creaked open. Inside were maps, papers, and a leather notebook tied with ribbon.
pages.illustration: Children kneeling beside the open trunk, pages and trinkets glowing faintly in warm attic light.

pages.text: Oliver flipped open the notebook. The first page read: 'The Secret of the Starlight Compass.'
pages.illustration: The notebook open in Oliver’s hands, glowing letters reading 'The Secret of the Starlight Compass' as Emma leans closer.

pages.text: “A treasure hunt!” Emma gasped. Tiny sketches of constellations dotted the margins of each page.
pages.illustration: A close-up of the notebook showing constellations, symbols, and hand-drawn arrows connecting stars.

pages.text: They followed the first clue: 'Where light meets wood and whispers sleep.'
pages.illustration: The children puzzling over the clue beside attic beams and an old window where moonlight pours in.

pages.text: Oliver spotted a wooden birdcage hanging near the window. Inside was a rolled note tied with blue thread.
pages.illustration: A small birdcage swinging gently by the window with a glowing paper inside.

pages.text: The note read: 'Seek the feather that never fell.' Emma looked at the paintings on the wall and smiled.
pages.illustration: Emma pointing to a framed painting of a bird mid-flight, feathers frozen in time.

pages.text: Behind the painting, they found a small compartment with an old magnifying glass and a silver locket.
pages.illustration: Oliver holding up a magnifying glass while Emma opens a tiny hidden door revealing the locket.

pages.text: Inside the locket was a photo of a young woman and a man smiling in front of the same attic window.
pages.illustration: Close-up of the locket glowing in Emma’s hand, showing an old sepia photograph.

pages.text: On the back of the photo, neat handwriting said: 'Follow the stars to where our story began.'
pages.illustration: Emma holding the photo under the attic’s star-shaped window as the night sky glimmers outside.

pages.text: They turned off the attic light. Through the window, tiny stars lined up like arrows across the sky.
pages.illustration: Children gazing out the round attic window, the Milky Way reflected in their eyes.

pages.text: The starlight pointed toward a shelf of books. One book had a glowing spine and the same ribbon as the notebook.
pages.illustration: A row of old books, one shimmering faintly while dust motes float around it.

pages.text: Inside the book were letters—love notes between the woman and man from the locket. They were explorers!
pages.illustration: Emma and Oliver surrounded by floating papers, illustrations of maps and hearts drawn in the margins.

pages.text: One letter said: 'We’ll hide our compass where dreams rest and daylight dances.'
pages.illustration: Oliver reading aloud as Emma imagines explorers in the attic, lantern light mixing with stars.

pages.text: They looked around the room until Emma whispered, 'The old toy chest!' They opened it together.
pages.illustration: The children kneeling by a wooden toy chest, their faces lit with excitement and soft golden glow.

pages.text: Inside, wrapped in velvet, was a brass compass etched with tiny stars. It shimmered like the night sky.
pages.illustration: A glowing compass resting on blue velvet, reflecting light on the children’s amazed faces.

pages.text: Emma smiled. 'It’s not just a treasure—it’s their story. And now it’s ours too.'
pages.illustration: Both children smiling warmly as they hold the compass together, surrounded by gentle starlight.

pages.text: They closed the trunk carefully. The stars outside twinkled as if winking goodnight to their secret in the attic.
pages.illustration: A peaceful final scene: the attic window glowing with starlight, the children descending the ladder, leaving the trunk safe and closed.
